Also, be sure to render the document into an HTML so that you get the full effect.hope it helps. (edited)


<!DOCTYPE html>






html_wide_tables








 


 










wide tables?


REF: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/kableExtra/vignettes/awesome_table_in_html.html



kableExtra + bootstrap




library(knitr)
library(data.table)
library(kableExtra)
kbl(head(cars)) %>%
  kable_paper(bootstrap_options = "striped", full_width = F)

title: 100_html_CSS_examples.qmd
text:
wide tables?
REF: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/kableExtra/vignettes/awesome_table_in_html.html

kableExtra + bootstrap
library(knitr)
library(data.table)
library(kableExtra)
kbl(head(cars)) %>%
  kable_paper(bootstrap_options = "striped", full_width = F) 
knitr::knit_exit()
{r attr.source="style='display:inline-block;'", collapse=TRUE} 1:10  # a sequence from 1 to 10 10:1  # in the reverse order https://bookdown.org/yihui/rmarkdown-cookbook/multi-column.html


Here is the first Div.
str(iris)


And this block will be put on the right:
plot(iris[, -5])


library(knitr)
#| column: page
#| label: tbl-cars
#| tbl-cap: "Cars"
#| tbl-colwidths: [10,10]

knitr::kable(head(cars))
